The following is a list of common abbreviations in Teriock Online.

Abbreviation Meaning Numerical Value
@Core[Armor Class]{AC} @Core[Armor Class]{Armor class} Yes
@Property[AP]{AP} @Property[AP]{Armor piercing} No
@Core[Armor Class]{AV} @Core[Armor Class]{Armor value} Yes
@Keyword[AV0]{AV0} This once meant "armor value equals zero", but now it just means "@Keyword[AV0]{AV0}". No
@Core[Block Interaction]{BV} @Core[Block Interaction]{Block value} Yes
@Core[Elder Sorcery]{ES} @Core[Elder Sorcery]{Elder Sorcery} No
@Core[Fluency Bonus]{F} @Core[Fluency Bonus]{Fluency bonus} Yes
@Core[GM]{GM} Gabriel man No
@Wiki[Core:HP]{HP} @Core[Hit Points and Mana Points]{Hit points} No
@Core[Intelligence]{INT} @Core[Intelligence]{Intelligence attribute} Yes
@Core[Leveling Up]{LVL} @Core[Leveling Up]{Total level} Yes
LARP Live action role playing No
@Wiki[Category:Mage classes]{MR} @Wiki[Category:Mage classes]{Ranks in mage classes} Yes
@Core[Movement]{MOV} @Core[Movement]{Movement attribute} Yes
@Wiki[Core:MP]{MP} @Core[Hit Points and Mana Points]{Mana points} No
@Core[Elder Sorcery]{OP} @Core[Elder Sorcery]{Order of power} No
@Core[Proficiency Bonus]{P} @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{Proficiency bonus} Yes
@Core[Perception]{PER} @Core[Perception]{Perception attribute} Yes
@Core[Presence]{PRES} @Core[Presence]{Presence tier} Yes
@Core[Style Bonus]{SB} @Core[Style Bonus]{Style bonus} No
@Wiki[Category:Semi classes]{SR} @Wiki[Category:Semi classes]{Ranks in semi classes} Yes
@Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE} @Wiki[Core:Size]{Size} Yes
@Core[Sneak]{SNK} @Core[Sneak]{Sneak attribute} Yes
@Core[Strength]{STR} @Core[Strength]{Strength attribute} Yes
@Core[Leveling Up]{RANK} @Core[Leveling Up]{Total rank} Yes
@Keyword[UB]{UB} @Keyword[UB]{Unblockable} No
@Core[Presence]{UNP} @Core[Presence]{Unused presence} Yes
@Wiki[Category:Warrior classes]{WR} @Wiki[Category:Warrior classes]{Ranks in warrior classes} Yes

In Teriock Online, everything a creature can do is determined by its @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}. These may be granted by the creature's species type, their @Wiki[Category:Classes]{classes}, magic items they use, or other @Wiki[Category:Traits]{traits} of theirs. By default, every creature is able to use any @Wiki[Category:Basic abilities]{basic abilities} so long as they meet whatever conditions are specified for the given @Wiki[Category:Basic abilities]{basic ability}.

Regardless of where it comes from, each Ability has the same underlying structure.

User

An Ability's User is simply the creature that is using the Ability. This is the same for all Abilities.

Target

An ability's target type determines what kinds of things can be affected by the Ability. Some of the most common ones are listed here.

Creature

Abilities with the Creature Target affect some sort of being. A "creature" doesn't necessarily have to be an animal, it may be an animated statue or a sentient plant. Check with your @Core[GM]{GM} if in doubt of whether something is a creature or not.

Limb

Rather than hitting an entire creature, some Abilities will say that they only hit arms, legs, or limbs. If these Abilities are @Core[Attack Interaction]{attacks}, then they slightly harder to land a hit with than ones that can hit a creature anywhere. They require hitting that creature's @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 2.

Vitals

Vitals Targeted Abilities need to hit a creature's head or other vital organs rather than landing anywhere. If these Abilities are @Core[Attack Interaction]{attacks}, then they require hitting a creature's @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 3.

Item

@Wiki[Category:Item target abilities]{Attacks that target items} need different @Core[Attack Interaction]{hit rolls} depending on the @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{type of item}.

  • Wielded items (such as @Wiki[Category:Weapons]{weapons} or @Wiki[Category:Shields]{shields}): @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 3 - @Core[Block Interaction]{BV}
  • Large worn items (such as @Wiki[Category:Armor]{armor} or cloaks): @Core[Armor Class]{AC}
  • @Wiki[Category:Small equipment]{Small} @Wiki[Category:Searchable equipment]{searchable items} (such as rings or amulets): @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 6

If an @Wiki[Category:Item target abilities]{ability that targets an item} is successfully @Core[Block Interaction]{blocked}, it automatically hits the item that @Core[Block Interaction]{blocked} it.

Area

Abilities that Target an Area do not have a precisely defined size. Rather than affect a small, cohesive space such as a campsite, a room in a dungeon, or a small shack.These abilities may not have a Range specified.

Self

Self targeted abilities affect @Core[Executer]{the creature that executes them}. They may not have a range specified.

Ability

Instead of targeting some person, place, or other physical thing, some @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} target other @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}. These include cases that target @Wiki[Category:Attack target abilities]{attack target abilities}, @Wiki[Category:Conjured spells]{conjured} @Wiki[Category:Spell target abilities]{spells}, or other types of @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.

Other

Some Ability Targets don't fit nearly into one of the aforementioned categories. In these cases, the Ability's Target will just say "Other".

Range

Each Ability has some Range over which it can be used. These depend on the Delivery and Target.

Delivery

Every Ability has one and only one @Wiki[Category:Delivery abilities]{delivery}. This always has at least two parts, a Source and Interaction.

Source

The Source of an Ability's Delivery is the means by which it is transmitted from the User to the Target. There are many possible Sources, but the most common ones are as follows.

Item

Item Sourced Abilities are transmitted from the User to the Target via one of the User's items. Some Abilities may only specify "item" as the Source. Others may give a more specific description such as "weapon", "shield", or "armor". These are all considered to be Sourced with items and are just shorthands for the type of item that can be used.

The Range of Item Sourced Abilities is that of the item.

Missile

Abilities with the missile source are those that would have spell stones in live action FanWar. These are most often @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks}, but do not have any physical weapon that mediates them. Instead, these Abilities may correspond to a ball of fire, a bolt of lightning, a gust of wind, or some other phenomenon. Missile @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} have @Core[Disadvantage]{disadvantage} on targets that have their executor within melee range. Missile sourced abilities also requite that the creature executing them have an open hand.

Note: A creature with @Ability[Staff Touch]{Staff Touch} wielding a @Wiki[Category:Magelore equipment]{magelore item} in their hand, counts as having that hand open.

Sight

Abilities sourced by sight do not require the user to literally see the target with their eyeballs. While that's still necessary in most cases, some creatures may have some sort of "@Wiki[Category:Sensory effects]{blindsight}" that allows them to "see" other creatures even when there's no light in the environment. Nevertheless, these abilities always require that the user have some sort of direct "visibility" of the target akin to seeing them directly. Regardless of how exactly the user sees the target, sight abilities can be used over some range that may not actually be as far as the user can see. For instance, @Ability[Duel]{Duel} operates by sight, but has a range of 30 feet even though the user may see the target from much further away.

Aura

Abilities with the aura delivery source are ones that could affect every target within some specified radius, centered on the @Core[Executer]{executer}. Unless specifically noted by the ability, the @Core[Executer]{executer} is not affected by @Wiki[Category:Aura delivery abilities]{aura abilities}.

Hand

Like with @Wiki[Category:Sight delivery abilities]{sight} and eyeballs, @Wiki[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hand delivery sourced abilities} don't require the user to physically have a dexterous humanoid hand with recognizable fingers. Some creatures with claws, tentacles, or other appendages can use Hand Abilities without problem. However, something of this nature is always required. If a creature that typically has @Equipment[Hand]{literal hands} has their arms @Ability[Hack]{Hacked} or has their @Equipment[Hand]{hands} cut off, then they are unable to use @Wiki[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hand delivered abilities}. It may be possible for them to find other ways to use these abilities in the future, but that's up to @Core[GM]{GM} discretion.

The range of @Wiki[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hand delivery sourced abilities} is the reach of the @Core[Executer]{executer's} arm (or other appendage). This depends in part on the creature's @Wiki[Core:Size]{size}, but is usually 5 feet.

Bite

Abilities with the @Wiki[Category:Bite delivery abilities]{bite delivery source} are similar to @Wiki[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hand abilities}, but they are transmitted with something that at least resembles a @Equipment[Mouth]{mouth} rather than a @Equipment[Hand]{hand}.

The range of @Wiki[Category:Bite delivery abilities]{bite delivered abilities} is the reach of the @Core[Executer]{executer's} neck (or other similar body part). This depends in part on the creature's @Wiki[Core:Size]{size}, but is usually 5 feet.

Self

Self Sourced Abilities are the simplest ones. They have no special means of transmission, but simply come from the User. This is sometimes used as a catch-all for Abilities that don't fit with any other Source.

Interaction

In addition to a Source, every Ability is mediated by one of four @Core[Interactions]{interactions}. This determines what types of dice rolls, if any, need to be done for an Ability to affect its Target. See the @Core[Interactions]{interactions} page for complete detail.

Other Delivery Modifiers

Some Abilities are always @Keyword[AV0]{AV0} or @Keyword[UB]{UB}. When this is the case, it's mentioned within the Delivery.

Delivery Packages

Abilities may be listed as @Wiki[Category:Strike delivery abilities]{strikes}, @Wiki[Category:Ritual delivery abilities]{rituals}, @Wiki[Category:Touch delivery abilities]{touches}, @Wiki[Category:Ball delivery abilities]{balls}, or @Wiki[Category:Ray delivery abilities]{rays}. These represent certain common deliveries composed out of the source and interaction primitives as well as other modifiers. What exactly these mean is listed in parentheses in the "delivery" section of relevant @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.

Execution or Casting Time

Each Ability has a specified amount of "time" it takes to use. For @Wiki[Category:Spells]{spells} this is called the "Casting" time. For @Wiki[Category:Skills]{skills} and other @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} this is the "Execution" time. This is always paired with the type of @Core[Maneuvers]{maneuver} (written in parentheses) the Ability operates under.

Make sure to read the @Core[Maneuvers]{maneuvers} page for complete information.

Duration

The duration of an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} is the maximum amount of time that that @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability's} effect applies for. Many abilities have an "end condition" that can apply before the full duration is reached. Other abilities have an "@Wiki[Category:Instant duration abilities]{instant}" duration which means the effect is simply applied at once. The duration of @Wiki[Category:Passive abilities]{passive abilities} describes the conditions under which they're in effect.

Power Sources

Every @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} is @Wiki[Category:Powered abilities]{powered} through some means. For many @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}, the power source is simply "@Wiki[Category:Martially powered abilities]{martial}", which means they stem from the physical capabilities of the user. Other abilities could be "@Wiki[Category:Magically powered abilities]{magical}", "@Wiki[Category:Spiritually powered abilities]{spiritual}", or powered through other means. For an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} to work, all power sources must be accessible.

Standard Abilities

Noted under the "delivery sources" section of an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability}, is whether it is considered @Wiki[Category:Standard abilities]{standard}. These @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} are typically those given by @Wiki[Category:Classes]{classes} or those that are particularly common, well known, or easy to interact with. Some @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} interact specifically with other standard abilities. @Wiki[Category:Conjured spells]{Standard spells} are referred to as @Wiki[Category:Conjured spells]{conjured} and @Wiki[Category:Semblant skills]{standard skills} as @Wiki[Category:Semblant skills]{semblant}.

Effect Types

Some Abilities are considered "effects" of various types. Effect types don't generally influence the way Abilities mechanically operate. However, many Abilities interact with different effect types in various ways.

Heightening

Some @Wiki[Category:Heightened abilities]{abilities} allow you to heighten them. In these cases, you can choose to spend additional @Wiki[Core:MP]{MP} as you execute the @Wiki[Category:Heightened abilities]{ability} and the effect will be altered in some way described in its "Heightened" text. Abilities that don't have this text cannot be heightened. You can only heighten @Wiki[Category:Heightened abilities]{abilities} you are @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} or @Core[Fluency Bonus]{fluent} in and, even then, can only heighten up to the corresponding bonus. If an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack ability} is heightened, it gets +1 to hit per level of heightening. If a @Wiki[Category:Feat abilities]{feat ability} is heightened, it gets +1 to the DC per level of heightening.

Components

Many @Wiki[Category:Component abilities]{abilities} require one or more components in order to be executed.

Verbal Components

If an @Wiki[Category:Verbal component abilities]{ability} has a verbal component, the creature executing it must be able to speak to do so. The must not be @Condition[Deaf]{deaf}.

Somatic Components

If an @Wiki[Category:Somatic component abilities]{ability} has a somatic component, the creature executing it must have at least one free hand to do so. If the creature has an @Damage[Hack]{arm hack} then it must have both hands free. If the creature has two @Damage[Hack]{arm hacks} then it cannot execute the @Wiki[Category:Somatic component abilities]{ability}.

Material Components

If an @Wiki[Category:Material component abilities]{ability} has a material component, the creature executing it must have the material component on hand to do so. The specific material component is listed in the @Wiki[Category:Material component abilities]{ability's} description. Material components are consumed by the ability unless otherwise noted.

Instead of targeting some person, place, or other physical thing, some @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} target other @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}. These include cases that target @Wiki[Category:Attack target abilities]{attack target abilities}, @Wiki[Category:Conjured spells]{conjured} @Wiki[Category:Spell target abilities]{spells}, or other types of @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.

Active maneuvers are done proactively within the time scale of a single turn. On each creature's turn, they may take up to three Actions in total. Every @Wiki[Category:Active abilities]{active ability} will specify how many of these actions it consumes. They may be @Wiki[Category:Single action abilities]{single actions}, @Wiki[Category:Double action abilities]{double actions}, or @Wiki[Category:Triple action abilities]{triple actions}. Some @Wiki[Category:Active abilities]{active abilities} may also be @Wiki[Category:Free action abilities]{free actions}. These not only don't consume a creature's actions, but can be done at any time (even on other creatures' turns)! However, they cannot be used in reaction to other @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.

Sometimes an effect will specify that you have Advantage on an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack}, @Wiki[Category:Feat abilities]{feat save}, @Keyword[Resistance]{resistance save}, or some other dice roll involving a single die. When this is the case, you roll that die twice and take the higher of the two rolls. If multiple sources would grant you Advantage, you still only roll the die twice. If you have both Advantage and @Core[Disadvantage]{disadvantage}, then you roll normally. This is the case even if you have different numbers of sources of Advantage and Disadvantage.

If you are @Condition[Hidden]{hidden}, then you have Advantage on @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} rolls against creatures that can't see you. If you make an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack}, then you roll [[/roll 2d20k1]] instead of the normal [[/roll 1d20]]. If the creature you're attacking is also @Condition[Hidden]{hidden}, then the Advantage from being @Condition[Hidden]{hidden} and the @Core[Disadvantage]{disadvantage} from them being @Condition[Hidden]{hidden} cancel out, resulting in a normal [[/roll 1d20]] roll.

Abilities that Target an Area do not have a precisely defined size. Rather than affect a small, cohesive space such as a campsite, a room in a dungeon, or a small shack.These abilities may not have a Range specified.

All @Wiki[Category:Armor]{armor} has an armor value referred to as its AV. When worn, this gives you an armor class (or AC) of 10 + AV. These numbers may seem low for people familiar with other systems, but that's because @Core[Block Interaction]{blocking} is a core part of the game. Some abilities such as @Ability[Unbreachability]{Unbreachability} will improve a creature's AC regardless of what @Wiki[Category:Armor]{armor} they are wearing. In Teriock Online, AV does not stack. This means if you have an ability like @Ability[Natural Hide]{Natural Hide} and then don @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{leather armor} that your AC does not change.

Many classes also have a maximum AV they can wear.

The most important interaction is the attack interaction, which is used whenever a weapon, body part, or missile would come into contact with a target. The attacker first makes an attack roll ([[/roll 1d20]]) against the target's @Core[Armor Class]{armor class} (AC). If the attacker is @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} with the @Core[Abilities]{ability} they are using, they add their @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} (P) to the roll. If this roll is equal to or greater than the target's @Core[Armor Class]{AC} (typically 10 + @Wiki[Core:AV]{AV}), the attack hits. If the roll is less than the target's AC, the attack misses. A natural 20 on the die is always a hit, and a natural 1 is always a miss. The consequence of a hit is described in the "On hit" section of the @Core[Abilities]{ability} that's used.

If the hit is from a natural 20, then the attack is a critical hit and the effect of the @Core[Abilities]{ability} "goes critical". If this changes anything about the effect, then it's described in the @Core[Abilities]{ability's} "On critical hit" section. Any creature that is @Condition[Up]{up} may choose to be hit by an attack, even if the attack would normally miss. This is called "Taking the hit". They cannot choose to take a critical hit.

Shields have @Property[Special]{special} rules regarding if a creature can attack.

@Equipment[Buckler Shield]{Buckler Shields}
Any type of item can be held in an arm with a buckler shield. But only @Wiki[Category:Small equipment]{small items} in this hand can be used to attack or block.
@Equipment[Large Shield]{Large Shields}
Any type of item can be held in an arm with a large shield. But no item in this hand can be used to attack or block.
@Equipment[Tower Shield]{Tower Shields}
Only @Wiki[Category:Small equipment]{small items} can be held in an arm with a tower shield. No item in this hand can be used to attack or block.

Multiple Attacks

Attacks are always associated with a hand. This could be the hand that uses a weapon, that casts a spell, or that performs an unarmed strike. The first attack you make with a given hand has no penalty to hit. Each subsequent attack you make with that hand in the same turn incurs a cumulative -3 attack penalty to hit. Your attack penalty resets to 0 at the end of your turn.

Lord Goobelthorp is wielding a @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in two hands. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -6 penalty to hit.

Kaflimbo is wielding a @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortsword} in each hand. The first attack they make with one of the @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortswords} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with their other @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortsword} in the same turn using @Ability[Off-Hand Attack]{Off-Hand Attack}, that attack also has no penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with one of the @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortswords} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit.

Tizzy Snomblom has a @Equipment[War Hammer]{war hammer} in one hand and a @Equipment[Tower Shield]{tower shield} in the other. The arm with the @Equipment[Tower Shield]{tower shield} is also holding a @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{dagger}, although they cannot attack with it. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -6 penalty to hit.

Flaxer Gogo has a @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} in one hand, a @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the other, and a @Equipment[Buckler Shield]{buckler shield} strapped to the arm with their @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger}. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} has no penalty to hit. Since they're using is @Equipment[Buckler Shield]{buckler shield} (and not some larger type of @Wiki[Category:Shields]{shield}), they can also make a second attack with the @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the same turn without incurring a penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} or the @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit.

Complete Attack and Block Interaction Routine

Abilities with the aura delivery source are ones that could affect every target within some specified radius, centered on the @Core[Executer]{executer}. Unless specifically noted by the ability, the @Core[Executer]{executer} is not affected by @Wiki[Category:Aura delivery abilities]{aura abilities}.

A creature type's battle rating is a measure of how powerful it is. In principle, it is equal to the @Core[Leveling Up]{level} of character that would be expected to be an even match for it in @Core[Combat]{combat}.

Abilities with the @Wiki[Category:Bite delivery abilities]{bite delivery source} are similar to @Wiki[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hand abilities}, but they are transmitted with something that at least resembles a @Equipment[Mouth]{mouth} rather than a @Equipment[Hand]{hand}.

The range of @Wiki[Category:Bite delivery abilities]{bite delivered abilities} is the reach of the @Core[Executer]{executer's} neck (or other similar body part). This depends in part on the creature's @Wiki[Core:Size]{size}, but is usually 5 feet.

If an attack hits, but has not gone critical, then the defender has a chance to block. In addition to the @Core[Armor Class]{AV} of @Wiki[Category:Armor]{armor}, every @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{other item} has some block value (BV). If the defender attempts an @Core[Abilities]{ability} that uses the block interaction, then they add the item's BV to their @Core[Armor Class]{armor class}. If the new total is greater than the attacker's attack roll, then the block succeeds. If the new total is less than or equal to the attacker's attack roll, then the block fails. The consequence of a successful or unsuccessful block are described in the "On success" and "On fail" section of the @Wiki[Category:Block abilities]{ability} that's used. For a @Ability[Basic Block]{Basic Block}, a successful block causes the attacking effect to @Core[Fizzles]{fizzle}.

Every time you block with the same item in the same @Core[Turns]{turn}, its BV is reduced by 1 (to a minimum of 0). This is referred to as the item's block penalty. @Wiki[Category:Blocking equipment]{blocking} items do not suffer this penalty.

Complete Attack and Block Interaction Routine

How much a creature can lift and carry is determined by its @Core[Strength]{STR} and @Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE}.

Carrying Capacity Under Size 5
Amount in Pounds Effect Upon Hitting Threshold
65 + (20 × @Core[Strength]{STR}) @Condition[Encumbered]{Lightly Encumbered}
130 + (40 × @Core[Strength]{STR}) @Condition[Encumbered]{Heavily Encumbered}
195 + (60 × @Core[Strength]{STR}) Cannot carry anything more
Carrying Capacity of Size 5 and Larger
Amount in Pounds Effect Upon Hitting Threshold
65 + (20 × (@Core[Strength]{STR} + (@Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE} - 5)²)) @Condition[Encumbered]{Lightly Encumbered}
130 + (40 × (@Core[Strength]{STR} + (@Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE} - 5)²)) @Condition[Encumbered]{Heavily Encumbered}
195 + (60 × (@Core[Strength]{STR} + (@Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE} - 5)²)) Cannot carry anything more

A creature may also push, drag, or lift a weight in pounds up to twice their carrying capacity. While pushing or dragging weight in excess of their carrying capacity, the creature's @Core[Movement Speed]{movement speed} drops to 5 feet.

Design Note: I have many spreadsheets of lame algebra to make sure the weight and carrying capacity scaling make physical sense (one has to scale on a power of 2 and the other on a power of 3), fit with our intuitions of strength on the human scale, and also allow creatures to be strong enough to carry their own bodies. It's actually a very limited set of values that that works for.
Design Note: Why use pounds instead of sizes? Because I hate the size abstraction, somehow still have no intuition for how many "sizes" of weight objects are, and it's also simplicity that isn't needed in the way it is for live action FanWar.

The amount a creature can carry is shown in the table below.

An @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} that cascades is one that executes again if it hits the target and does not @Core[Fizzles]{fizzle}. This can happen a maximum number of times equal to the value specified in the expansion range and occur sequentially, each new target being within the expansion range of the previous. You choose the additional targets. These extra executions do not count as new attacks for the purposes of @Core[Multiple Attacks]{attack penalties}, although they must still be rolled.

Combat in Teriock Online is broken into rounds and turns.

Rounds

Each round of combat is considered to take 5 seconds.

Initiative

At the start of combat, every participant rolls for initiative ([[/roll 1d20]] + @Core[Movement]{MOV} + @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{P}). This determines the combatants' turn order, with the higher rollers acting first. If another creature joins the combat partway through, they roll initiative as well and can act at times in accordance with their roll.

Surprise Rounds

Sometimes abilities or other circumstances will allow some combatants to get the upper hand on their foes by surprising them at the start of combat. When this happens, everyone still rolls for initiative, but the creatures that benefit from the surprise round are the only ones that get to act. Everyone else has their turns skipped.

Turns

On a creature's turn, they may make up to three actions. @Ability[Move]{Moving}, @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking}, and so on typically use some number of these actions. Creatures also have one reaction that can, in principle, be use at any time within a round. They regain their reaction at the start of their turn. Creatures cannot "save up" their actions or reactions between rounds or turns. Actions and reactions reset regardless of whether or not they're used.

In addition, some effects may begin, apply, or cease at the start or end of a creature's turn. These are specified within the relevant rules text.

Maneuvers

Everything a creature does in combat turn is codified in terms of @Core[Abilities]{abilities}. Each @Core[Abilities]{ability}, in turn, has one of four possible maneuvers that determine when it can be used.

Active Maneuvers

Active maneuvers are done proactively within the time scale of a single turn. On each creature's turn, they may take up to three Actions in total. Every @Wiki[Category:Active abilities]{active ability} will specify how many of these actions it consumes. They may be @Wiki[Category:Single action abilities]{single actions}, @Wiki[Category:Double action abilities]{double actions}, or @Wiki[Category:Triple action abilities]{triple actions}. Some @Wiki[Category:Active abilities]{active abilities} may also be @Wiki[Category:Free action abilities]{free actions}. These not only don't consume a creature's actions, but can be done at any time (even on other creatures' turns)! However, they cannot be used in reaction to other @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.

Reactive Maneuvers

Reactive maneuvers can only be done in response to some event that triggers them. Every reactive maneuver will specify what its triggering conditions are. These could be @Ability[Tumble]{taking damage}, @Ability[Resolve Conflict]{hearing another creature speak}, @Ability[Opportunity Attack]{another creature moving away from you}, or anything else. Each creature has only one @Wiki[Category:Reaction abilities]{reaction} per turn. However, some @Wiki[Category:Reactive abilities]{reactive abilities} are @Wiki[Category:Free reaction abilities]{free reactions}. These have no limit on the number of times they can be used, so long as their triggering condition is met every time.

The order of reactive maneuver resolution is determined by a "last in, first out" stack. So if so if a creature casts @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball}, and another casts @Ability[Dispel Magic]{Dispel Magic}, and the creature that first cast @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball} casts @Ability[Dispel Magic]{Dispel Magic} on the first dispel, then the @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball} resolves. A given creature can only use a given @Wiki[Category:Reactive abilities]{reactive ability} once within a given stack.

Passive Maneuvers

Passive maneuvers act in the background and don't require any decision to use. @Wiki[Category:Passive abilities]{passive abilities} will always have a duration listed that tell you when they are and aren't in effect.

Note: @Wiki[Category:Passive abilities]{passive abilities} are in effect whether you like them or not. You can not simply choose to not use them.

Slow Maneuvers

Slow maneuvers are those that take longer than a single turn to execute. Some may be on the scale of a @Wiki[Category:Short rest abilities]{short} or @Wiki[Category:Long rest abilities]{long rest}, in which case they cannot be used in combat. Other @Wiki[Category:Slow abilities]{slow abilities}, such as most @Wiki[Category:Ritual delivery abilities]{rituals}, have a more precise execution time (or casting time) specified in seconds, minutes, hours, or some other defined unit of time. These can be done during combat so long as a round doesn't pass without the creature executing them using @Ability[Sustain]{Sustain} at least once.

pages.name: Complete Attack and Block Interaction Routine

text.content:
Many @Wiki[Category:Component abilities]{abilities} require one or more components in order to be executed.

Verbal Components

If an @Wiki[Category:Verbal component abilities]{ability} has a verbal component, the creature executing it must be able to speak to do so. The must not be @Condition[Deaf]{deaf}.

Somatic Components

If an @Wiki[Category:Somatic component abilities]{ability} has a somatic component, the creature executing it must have at least one free hand to do so. If the creature has an @Damage[Hack]{arm hack} then it must have both hands free. If the creature has two @Damage[Hack]{arm hacks} then it cannot execute the @Wiki[Category:Somatic component abilities]{ability}.

Material Components

If an @Wiki[Category:Material component abilities]{ability} has a material component, the creature executing it must have the material component on hand to do so. The specific material component is listed in the @Wiki[Category:Material component abilities]{ability's} description. Material components are consumed by the ability unless otherwise noted.

@Wiki[Category:Cost abilities]{Some abilities} have costs that must be spent in order to use them. These could be @Wiki[Category:HP cost abilities]{HP}, @Wiki[Category:MP cost abilities]{MP}, or something else. If the cost is not paid, then the @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} does not execute.

Half Cover
+2 bonus to @Core[Armor Class]{AC} and @Core[Movement]{MOV} @Core[Feat Interaction]{feat saves}
Three-quarters Cover
+5 bonus to @Core[Armor Class]{AC} and @Core[Movement]{MOV} @Core[Feat Interaction]{feat saves}
Full Cover
Can't be targeted directly by @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.

Abilities with the Creature Target affect some sort of being. A "creature" doesn't necessarily have to be an animal, it may be an animated statue or a sentient plant. Check with your @Core[GM]{GM} if in doubt of whether something is a creature or not.

Every @Wiki[Category:Weapons]{weapon} has a base damage it deals. This is represented by some die ([[/roll d4]], [[/roll d6]], [[/roll d8]], etc.). Assuming nothing else modifies the damage dealt, if a creature hits another with a @Ability[Basic Attack]{Basic Attack}, it's player rolls this damage die and the target takes that much damage.

Many @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} and other effects modify the amount of damage an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} deals (through @Wiki[Keyword:Boosted Damage]{boosting}, @Wiki[Keyword:Deboosted Damage]{deboosting}, @Ability[Might Strike]{adding additional damage dice}, or other means). These damage dice may also have @Wiki[Category:Damage types]{damage types} associated with them that may incur additional effects. Damage may have multiple types. If no type is specified, the damage is considered to be "@Damage[Mundane]{mundane}".

The total set of all damage dice that would be rolled (including types) is referred to as standard damage. If an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} says it "deals standard damage" it means deals damage, considering all relevant modifiers in the process. Some @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} also deal critical damage. In these cases, roll each damage die twice (after applying all @Wiki[Keyword:Boosted Damage]{boosts} and @Wiki[Keyword:Deboosted Damage]{deboosts}) and deal that much damage instead. This doesn't automatically double static increases or decreases to the amount of damage dealt, unless explicitly stated (such as by @Ability[Slay]{Slay}).

If someone is @Condition[Down]{dropped} by an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} or other source of damage that includes dice of several @Wiki[Category:Damage types]{damage types}, then they are considered to have been @Condition[Down]{dropped} by all those @Wiki[Category:Damage types]{damage types}.

Note: Not all @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} deal damage (e.g. @Ability[Snare]{Snare}. And, of those that do, not all deal standard damage (e.g. @Ability[Flame Ray]{Flame Ray}). The effect of an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} is that which is described in its "On hit" section. And the effect of a critical hit is that which is described in its "On critical hit" section (if it has one). If an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} does not say it deals critical damage, then that is not something it does.

Abilities may be listed as @Wiki[Category:Strike delivery abilities]{strikes}, @Wiki[Category:Ritual delivery abilities]{rituals}, @Wiki[Category:Touch delivery abilities]{touches}, @Wiki[Category:Ball delivery abilities]{balls}, or @Wiki[Category:Ray delivery abilities]{rays}. These represent certain common deliveries composed out of the source and interaction primitives as well as other modifiers. What exactly these mean is listed in parentheses in the "delivery" section of relevant @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.
An @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} that detonates is one that executes again as an @Wiki[Category:Aura delivery abilities]{aura} if it hits its initial target and does not @Core[Fizzles]{fizzle}.

Sometimes an effect will specify that you have Disadvantage on an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack}, @Wiki[Category:Feat abilities]{feat save}, @Keyword[Resistance]{resistance save}, or some other dice roll involving a single die. When this is the case, you roll that die twice and take the lower of the two rolls. If multiple sources would impose Disadvantage, you still only roll the die twice. If you have both Disadvantage and @Core[Advantage]{advantage}, then you roll normally. This is the case even if you have different numbers of sources of Disadvantage and Advantage.

If you are @Condition[Blind]{blind}, then you have Disadvantage on @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack} rolls against creatures that you can't see. If you make an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack}, then you roll [[/roll 2d20kl1]] instead of the normal [[/roll 1d20]]. If the creature you're attacking is also @Condition[Blind]{blind}, then the Disadvantage from being @Condition[Blind]{blind} and the @Core[Advantage]{advantage} from them being @Wiki[Condition:Blinded]{blinded} cancel out, resulting in a normal [[/roll 1d20]] roll.

A creature can hold it's breath for 30 seconds plus a length of time determined by it's available @Wiki[Core:Hit Dice]{hit dice}. For each [[/roll d10]], they can hold their breath for an additional 30 seconds. For each [[/roll d12]], they can hold their breath for an additional 1 minute.

The duration of an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} is the maximum amount of time that that @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability's} effect applies for. Many abilities have an "end condition" that can apply before the full duration is reached. Other abilities have an "@Wiki[Category:Instant duration abilities]{instant}" duration which means the effect is simply applied at once. The duration of @Wiki[Category:Passive abilities]{passive abilities} describes the conditions under which they're in effect.

An effect is a catch-all term for "something that does something". Some types of effects merely describe an aspect of an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} with no additional rules. Others (like @Wiki[Category:Knockout effects]{knockout effects} or @Wiki[Category:Transformation effects]{transformation effects}) have rules for how they operate built into the effect itself.

Your @Core[GM]{GM} has not decided on a full set of spell creation rules yet. Don't ask him about it. Don't suggest anything to him. He doesn't want to hear it. Asking or suggesting at this time will count as a death for your highest level character. However, @Wiki[Category:Elder Sorcery words]{the words exist}.
The executer of an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} is the creature that executes it.

An ability that expands is one that has special rules that may give it additional targets. These are specific to the type of expansion (such as @Core[Cascade Expansion]{cascades} and @Core[Detonate Expansion]{detonations}).

The feat interaction (or "feat save interaction") is used whenever a target would have the chance to respond to an @Core[Abilities]{ability} that doesn't hit them physically (such as area of effect abilities like @Wiki[Category:Aura delivery abilities]{auras}). Any @Core[Abilities]{ability} using the feat interaction has a "Saving feature" section which describes which @Wiki[Core:Attributes]{attribute} the target must use to make the save. For instance, if an ability requires a "feat of strength" to make the save, then the target will roll [[/roll 1d20]] + @Wiki[Core:STR]{STR}. If they are @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in the attribute they are saving with, they will add their @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} to the roll as well. If the roll is equal to or greater than the save DC then the save succeeds. If the roll is less than the save DC then the save fails. The consequence of a successful or unsuccessful save are described in the "On success" and "On fail" section of the @Core[Abilities]{ability} that's used. Some feats may also be able to "go critical" if the save is a natural 1.

The save DC depends on the creature using the @Core[Abilities]{ability}. If they're @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in the ability, then the save DC is 10 + @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{P}. If not, then it's just 10.

Complete Feat Interaction Routine
If an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} or something else, then it has no effect.

A character's fluency bonus increases as they @Core[Leveling Up]{level up}.

As a shorthand, your fluency bonus may sometimes be written a "F".

The levels at which characters gain increased Proficiency are shown highlighted in the table below.

Tradecraft Fluencies

As you rank up, you get the option to take additional tradecrafts, or gain a fluency in a tradecraft you already have. A tradecraft fluency is a more tailored form of the tradecraft it corresponds to. For instance, you could be a @Tradecraft[Historian]{historian} with a fluency in ancient Shaloban history, a @Tradecraft[Tailor]{tailor} with a fluency in wizard robes, or an @Tradecraft[Enforcer]{enforcer} with a fluency in intimidating homeless people. When you make a tradecraft check where your fluency is relevant, you add your fluency bonus (F) instead of your @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} (P) to the roll. The @Core[GM]{GM} may also tailor the results of your check with regards to your fluency.

Game Master
You find what looks like an old pirate map.
Player
Can I try and make out the symbols on it? I'm a @Tradecraft[Cartographer]{cartographer} with a fluency in nautical directions.
Game Master
Sure thing. Roll for it.
Player
Rolls [[/roll 1d20+6]] because they're fluent in this and @Core[Leveling Up]{level 29}.
I rolled 19.
Game Master
You recognize a lot of the markings as referring to whirlpools and sea dragons. It's your choice whether you want to avoid or go into those areas.

GM is short for Gabriel Man, which is a special role in the game. GM has the highest authority in the game, and can manage all players and game content. The GM can alter rules for the game at will. Regardless of what the player does, GM can see it. 👀

Like with @Wiki[Category:Sight delivery abilities]{sight} and eyeballs, @Wiki[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hand delivery sourced abilities} don't require the user to physically have a dexterous humanoid hand with recognizable fingers. Some creatures with claws, tentacles, or other appendages can use Hand Abilities without problem. However, something of this nature is always required. If a creature that typically has @Equipment[Hand]{literal hands} has their arms @Ability[Hack]{Hacked} or has their @Equipment[Hand]{hands} cut off, then they are unable to use @Wiki[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hand delivered abilities}. It may be possible for them to find other ways to use these abilities in the future, but that's up to @Core[GM]{GM} discretion.

The range of @Wiki[Category:Hand delivery abilities]{hand delivery sourced abilities} is the reach of the @Core[Executer]{executer's} arm (or other appendage). This depends in part on the creature's @Wiki[Core:Size]{size}, but is usually 5 feet.

Someone receiving healing may instantly spend a @Wiki[Core:HP]{hit die} to recover that many @Wiki[Core:HP]{HP} or may recover one @Damage[Hack]{hack damage}. Healing may also typically be used for damage. If the target is capable of taking healing for damage (such as if they're @Wiki[Category:Undead creatures]{undead}), then they must roll their largest hit die and take that much @Damage[Holy]{holy damage}. This does not consume any of their hit dice. If a creature that's @Condition[Unconscious]{unconscious} receives healing, they are @Keyword[Awaken]{awakened}.

Design Note: I'm open to getting rid of the Hit Dice healing limitation. It might be far too limiting. There might also be versions of it that are better. I do really want to make sure that all healing has restrictions on how much it can be done though. The main reason for the Hit Dice limit is that it was a clear, elegant, and blanket way to apply a restriction to all healing without having to rethink each individual source of it. But we might just move that direction anyways.

Some @Wiki[Category:Heightened abilities]{abilities} allow you to heighten them. In these cases, you can choose to spend additional @Wiki[Core:MP]{MP} as you execute the @Wiki[Category:Heightened abilities]{ability} and the effect will be altered in some way described in its "Heightened" text. Abilities that don't have this text cannot be heightened. You can only heighten @Wiki[Category:Heightened abilities]{abilities} you are @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} or @Core[Fluency Bonus]{fluent} in and, even then, can only heighten up to the corresponding bonus. If an @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attack ability} is heightened, it gets +1 to hit per level of heightening. If a @Wiki[Category:Feat abilities]{feat ability} is heightened, it gets +1 to the DC per level of heightening.

Unlike in live action FanWar, characters in Teriock Online have many Hit Points (HP) and Mana Points (MP). And as characters level up, they continue to gain more. Partway through every rank, characters gain a hit die and a mana die. The type of die (5 HP ([[/roll 1d8]]), 6 HP ([[/roll 1d10]]), or 7 HP ([[/roll 1d12]])) determines how much a character's maximum HP or MP increases by with each rank (3, 4, and 5 respectively). Which type of die is determined by the type of class (@Wiki[Category:Warrior classes]{warrior}, @Wiki[Category:Semi classes]{semi}, or @Wiki[Category:Mage classes]{mage}) that the character is. Journeymen count as @Wiki[Category:Semi classes]{semis} for this purpose. At @Core[Leveling Up]{level 1}, characters have maximum HP and MP of 1 each. They get their first hit die and mana die at level 5 (both 6 HP ([[/roll 1d10]])s), and then get different ones as they keep ranking up.

Hit dice (but not mana dice) can be expended for @Core[Healing]{healing} or during a @Core[Short Rest]{short rest}. Both hit dice and mana dice are regained during a @Core[Long Rest]{long rest}.

The levels at which characters gain HP and MP are shown highlighted in the table below.

At the start of combat, every participant rolls for initiative ([[/roll 1d20]] + @Core[Movement]{MOV} + @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{P}). This determines the combatants' turn order, with the higher rollers acting first. If another creature joins the combat partway through, they roll initiative as well and can act at times in accordance with their roll.

A creature's intelligence (abbreviated as INT) is a measure of its mental acuity. It has no standard intrinsic mechanical effects on its own. By default, a creature's INT is 0, but there are @Wiki[Category:INT setting abilities]{various abilities that set it to different values}.

Abilities that affect INT

  • @Ability[Dense Intelligence]{Dense Intelligence}

Every @Core[Abilities]{ability} in Teriock Online is mediated by one of four Interactions. There are also several responses that may come into play.

Interactions

Attack Interaction

The most important interaction is the attack interaction, which is used whenever a weapon, body part, or missile would come into contact with a target. The attacker first makes an attack roll ([[/roll 1d20]]) against the target's @Core[Armor Class]{armor class} (AC). If the attacker is @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} with the @Core[Abilities]{ability} they are using, they add their @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} (P) to the roll. If this roll is equal to or greater than the target's @Core[Armor Class]{AC} (typically 10 + @Wiki[Core:AV]{AV}), the attack hits. If the roll is less than the target's AC, the attack misses. A natural 20 on the die is always a hit, and a natural 1 is always a miss. The consequence of a hit is described in the "On hit" section of the @Core[Abilities]{ability} that's used.

If the hit is from a natural 20, then the attack is a critical hit and the effect of the @Core[Abilities]{ability} "goes critical". If this changes anything about the effect, then it's described in the @Core[Abilities]{ability's} "On critical hit" section. Any creature that is @Condition[Up]{up} may choose to be hit by an attack, even if the attack would normally miss. This is called "Taking the hit". They cannot choose to take a critical hit.

Shields have @Property[Special]{special} rules regarding if a creature can attack.

@Equipment[Buckler Shield]{Buckler Shields}
Any type of item can be held in an arm with a buckler shield. But only @Wiki[Category:Small equipment]{small items} in this hand can be used to attack or block.
@Equipment[Large Shield]{Large Shields}
Any type of item can be held in an arm with a large shield. But no item in this hand can be used to attack or block.
@Equipment[Tower Shield]{Tower Shields}
Only @Wiki[Category:Small equipment]{small items} can be held in an arm with a tower shield. No item in this hand can be used to attack or block.

Multiple Attacks

Attacks are always associated with a hand. This could be the hand that uses a weapon, that casts a spell, or that performs an unarmed strike. The first attack you make with a given hand has no penalty to hit. Each subsequent attack you make with that hand in the same turn incurs a cumulative -3 attack penalty to hit. Your attack penalty resets to 0 at the end of your turn.

Lord Goobelthorp is wielding a @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in two hands. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -6 penalty to hit.

Kaflimbo is wielding a @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortsword} in each hand. The first attack they make with one of the @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortswords} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with their other @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortsword} in the same turn using @Ability[Off-Hand Attack]{Off-Hand Attack}, that attack also has no penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with one of the @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortswords} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit.

Tizzy Snomblom has a @Equipment[War Hammer]{war hammer} in one hand and a @Equipment[Tower Shield]{tower shield} in the other. The arm with the @Equipment[Tower Shield]{tower shield} is also holding a @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{dagger}, although they cannot attack with it. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -6 penalty to hit.

Flaxer Gogo has a @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} in one hand, a @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the other, and a @Equipment[Buckler Shield]{buckler shield} strapped to the arm with their @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger}. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} has no penalty to hit. Since they're using is @Equipment[Buckler Shield]{buckler shield} (and not some larger type of @Wiki[Category:Shields]{shield}), they can also make a second attack with the @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the same turn without incurring a penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} or the @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit.

Block Interaction

If an attack hits, but has not gone critical, then the defender has a chance to block. In addition to the @Core[Armor Class]{AV} of @Wiki[Category:Armor]{armor}, every @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{other item} has some block value (BV). If the defender attempts an @Core[Abilities]{ability} that uses the block interaction, then they add the item's BV to their @Core[Armor Class]{armor class}. If the new total is greater than the attacker's attack roll, then the block succeeds. If the new total is less than or equal to the attacker's attack roll, then the block fails. The consequence of a successful or unsuccessful block are described in the "On success" and "On fail" section of the @Wiki[Category:Block abilities]{ability} that's used. For a @Ability[Basic Block]{Basic Block}, a successful block causes the attacking effect to @Core[Fizzles]{fizzle}.

Every time you block with the same item in the same @Core[Turns]{turn}, its BV is reduced by 1 (to a minimum of 0). This is referred to as the item's block penalty. @Wiki[Category:Blocking equipment]{blocking} items do not suffer this penalty.

Feat Interaction

The feat interaction (or "feat save interaction") is used whenever a target would have the chance to respond to an @Core[Abilities]{ability} that doesn't hit them physically (such as area of effect abilities like @Wiki[Category:Aura delivery abilities]{auras}). Any @Core[Abilities]{ability} using the feat interaction has a "Saving feature" section which describes which @Wiki[Core:Attributes]{attribute} the target must use to make the save. For instance, if an ability requires a "feat of strength" to make the save, then the target will roll [[/roll 1d20]] + @Wiki[Core:STR]{STR}. If they are @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in the attribute they are saving with, they will add their @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} to the roll as well. If the roll is equal to or greater than the save DC then the save succeeds. If the roll is less than the save DC then the save fails. The consequence of a successful or unsuccessful save are described in the "On success" and "On fail" section of the @Core[Abilities]{ability} that's used. Some feats may also be able to "go critical" if the save is a natural 1.

The save DC depends on the creature using the @Core[Abilities]{ability}. If they're @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in the ability, then the save DC is 10 + @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{P}. If not, then it's just 10.

Manifest Interaction

The final interaction is the manifest Interaction. It's by far the simplest and is used whenever an effect "just happens". There's no built in way to deal with a manifest, only responses like @Keyword[Resistance]{resistances} and @Keyword[Immunity]{immunities}.


Responses

Resistances

Some @Core[Abilities]{abilities} grant Resistances to certain effects. Rather than being "absolute" like in live action FanWar, Resistances in Teriock Online have only a chance of stopping an effect. When a creature would be affected by something they are resistant to, they make a resistance save. This is a DC 10 [[/roll d20]] roll that they add their @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} to if they are @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in the @Core[Abilities]{ability} that grants them their resistance. On a success, the target is not affected by whatever was going to happen to them. On a fail, they are. Resistance saves cannot be failed automatically. Only one resistance save can be attempted per interaction. A resistance cannot stop a @Keyword[Warded]{warded} @Core[Abilities]{ability}.

Immunities

If you are immune to something, it does not work against you at all. A @Keyword[Warded]{warded} @Core[Abilities]{ability} does not cut through immunities.

Order of Operations

As a rule of thumb, the basic rules of Interactions happen first, followed by Immunities, then Resistances. In case it's needed, the complete interaction routines are provided below.

Item Sourced Abilities are transmitted from the User to the Target via one of the User's items. Some Abilities may only specify "item" as the Source. Others may give a more specific description such as "weapon", "shield", or "armor". These are all considered to be Sourced with items and are just shorthands for the type of item that can be used.

The Range of Item Sourced Abilities is that of the item.

@Wiki[Category:Item target abilities]{Attacks that target items} need different @Core[Attack Interaction]{hit rolls} depending on the @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{type of item}.

  • Wielded items (such as @Wiki[Category:Weapons]{weapons} or @Wiki[Category:Shields]{shields}): @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 3 - @Core[Block Interaction]{BV}
  • Large worn items (such as @Wiki[Category:Armor]{armor} or cloaks): @Core[Armor Class]{AC}
  • @Wiki[Category:Small equipment]{Small} @Wiki[Category:Searchable equipment]{searchable items} (such as rings or amulets): @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 6

If an @Wiki[Category:Item target abilities]{ability that targets an item} is successfully @Core[Block Interaction]{blocked}, it automatically hits the item that @Core[Block Interaction]{blocked} it.

Rather than hitting an entire creature, some Abilities will say that they only hit arms, legs, or limbs. If these Abilities are @Core[Attack Interaction]{attacks}, then they slightly harder to land a hit with than ones that can hit a creature anywhere. They require hitting that creature's @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 2.

A long rest is a period of extended downtime, at least 8 hours long, during which a creature sleeps or performs light activity: reading, talking, eating, or standing watch for no more than 2 hours. If the rest is interrupted by a period of strenuous activity—at least 1 hour of walking, fighting, casting spells, or similar adventuring activity—the creatures must begin the rest again to gain any benefit from it.

Note: Your @Core[GM]{GM} may decide on a different time period or conditions for a long rest.

Some @Wiki[Category:Long rest abilities]{abilities} (such as @Ability[Elder Sorcery Creation]{Elder Sorcery Creation}) have "long rest" as their execution time. A creature may choose to do one of these during their long rest.

At the end of a long rest, a creature regains all lost @Wiki[Core:HP]{HP}. The creature also regains all spent @Wiki[Core:HP]{hit dice}.

Everything a creature does in combat turn is codified in terms of @Core[Abilities]{abilities}. Each @Core[Abilities]{ability}, in turn, has one of four possible maneuvers that determine when it can be used.

Active Maneuvers

Active maneuvers are done proactively within the time scale of a single turn. On each creature's turn, they may take up to three Actions in total. Every @Wiki[Category:Active abilities]{active ability} will specify how many of these actions it consumes. They may be @Wiki[Category:Single action abilities]{single actions}, @Wiki[Category:Double action abilities]{double actions}, or @Wiki[Category:Triple action abilities]{triple actions}. Some @Wiki[Category:Active abilities]{active abilities} may also be @Wiki[Category:Free action abilities]{free actions}. These not only don't consume a creature's actions, but can be done at any time (even on other creatures' turns)! However, they cannot be used in reaction to other @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.

Reactive Maneuvers

Reactive maneuvers can only be done in response to some event that triggers them. Every reactive maneuver will specify what its triggering conditions are. These could be @Ability[Tumble]{taking damage}, @Ability[Resolve Conflict]{hearing another creature speak}, @Ability[Opportunity Attack]{another creature moving away from you}, or anything else. Each creature has only one @Wiki[Category:Reaction abilities]{reaction} per turn. However, some @Wiki[Category:Reactive abilities]{reactive abilities} are @Wiki[Category:Free reaction abilities]{free reactions}. These have no limit on the number of times they can be used, so long as their triggering condition is met every time.

The order of reactive maneuver resolution is determined by a "last in, first out" stack. So if so if a creature casts @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball}, and another casts @Ability[Dispel Magic]{Dispel Magic}, and the creature that first cast @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball} casts @Ability[Dispel Magic]{Dispel Magic} on the first dispel, then the @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball} resolves. A given creature can only use a given @Wiki[Category:Reactive abilities]{reactive ability} once within a given stack.

Passive Maneuvers

Passive maneuvers act in the background and don't require any decision to use. @Wiki[Category:Passive abilities]{passive abilities} will always have a duration listed that tell you when they are and aren't in effect.

Note: @Wiki[Category:Passive abilities]{passive abilities} are in effect whether you like them or not. You can not simply choose to not use them.

Slow Maneuvers

Slow maneuvers are those that take longer than a single turn to execute. Some may be on the scale of a @Wiki[Category:Short rest abilities]{short} or @Wiki[Category:Long rest abilities]{long rest}, in which case they cannot be used in combat. Other @Wiki[Category:Slow abilities]{slow abilities}, such as most @Wiki[Category:Ritual delivery abilities]{rituals}, have a more precise execution time (or casting time) specified in seconds, minutes, hours, or some other defined unit of time. These can be done during combat so long as a round doesn't pass without the creature executing them using @Ability[Sustain]{Sustain} at least once.

The final interaction is the manifest Interaction. It's by far the simplest and is used whenever an effect "just happens". There's no built in way to deal with a manifest, only responses like @Keyword[Resistance]{resistances} and @Keyword[Immunity]{immunities}.

Complete Manifest Interaction Routine

If an @Wiki[Category:Material component abilities]{ability} has a material component, the creature executing it must have the material component on hand to do so. The specific material component is listed in the @Wiki[Category:Material component abilities]{ability's} description. Material components are consumed by the ability unless otherwise noted.

Abilities with the missile source are those that would have spell stones in live action FanWar. These are most often @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks}, but do not have any physical weapon that mediates them. Instead, these Abilities may correspond to a ball of fire, a bolt of lightning, a gust of wind, or some other phenomenon. Missile @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attacks} have @Core[Disadvantage]{disadvantage} on targets that have their executor within melee range. Missile sourced abilities also requite that the creature executing them have an open hand.

Note: A creature with @Ability[Staff Touch]{Staff Touch} wielding a @Wiki[Category:Magelore equipment]{magelore item} in their hand, counts as having that hand open.

A creature's movement (abbreviated as MOV) is a measure of how quickly it can move. By default, a creature's MOV is 0, but there are @Wiki[Category:MOV setting abilities]{various abilities that set it to different values}.

Abilities that affect MOV

Movement Speed

A creature's base movement speed determines the maximum amount they can @Ability[Move]{Move} in a single action under normal conditions. It is determined by the creature's MOV attribute and is equal to 30 + (10 × MOV) in feet per action. A creature's base movement speed alone does not actually determine how far it can move in practice. Every creature has speeds for different types of movement, such as walking, leaping, swimming, climbing, and flying. The possible speed adjustments are double, normal, half, quarter, and none. Moving 5 feet at half speed uses 10 feet of movement, while moving 5 feet at double speed uses only 2.5 feet of movement. The following table summarizes the different movement speed adjustments.

Movement Speed Adjustments
Step Speed Adjustment Cost of Moving 5 Feet
4 Double 2.5 feet
3 Normal 5 feet
2 Half 10 feet
1 Quarter 20 feet
0 None Cannot move in this way at all

The default speed adjustments for different types of movement are as follows.

Default Movement Speed Adjustments
Move Type Speed Adjustment
Walk Speed Normal
Difficult Terrain Speed Half
Crawl Speed Quarter
Swim Speed Quarter
Climb Speed Quarter
@Condition[Hidden]{Hidden Speed} Quarter
Leap Speed (horizontal) Quarter
Leap Speed (vertical) None
Fly Speed None
Dig Speed None
Dive Speed None

Attacks are always associated with a hand. This could be the hand that uses a weapon, that casts a spell, or that performs an unarmed strike. The first attack you make with a given hand has no penalty to hit. Each subsequent attack you make with that hand in the same turn incurs a cumulative -3 attack penalty to hit. Your attack penalty resets to 0 at the end of your turn.

Lord Goobelthorp is wielding a @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in two hands. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[Claymore]{claymore} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -6 penalty to hit.

Kaflimbo is wielding a @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortsword} in each hand. The first attack they make with one of the @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortswords} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with their other @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortsword} in the same turn using @Ability[Off-Hand Attack]{Off-Hand Attack}, that attack also has no penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with one of the @Equipment[Shortsword]{shortswords} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit.

Tizzy Snomblom has a @Equipment[War Hammer]{war hammer} in one hand and a @Equipment[Tower Shield]{tower shield} in the other. The arm with the @Equipment[Tower Shield]{tower shield} is also holding a @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{dagger}, although they cannot attack with it. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} has no penalty to hit. If they make a second attack with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[War Hammer]{hammer} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -6 penalty to hit.

Flaxer Gogo has a @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} in one hand, a @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the other, and a @Equipment[Buckler Shield]{buckler shield} strapped to the arm with their @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger}. The first attack they make with the @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} has no penalty to hit. Since they're using is @Equipment[Buckler Shield]{buckler shield} (and not some larger type of @Wiki[Category:Shields]{shield}), they can also make a second attack with the @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the same turn without incurring a penalty to hit. If they make a third attack with the @Equipment[Longsword]{longsword} or the @Equipment[Dagger]{dagger} in the same turn, that attack incurs a -3 penalty to hit.
Some Ability Targets don't fit nearly into one of the aforementioned categories. In these cases, the Ability's Target will just say "Other".

Passive maneuvers act in the background and don't require any decision to use. @Wiki[Category:Passive abilities]{passive abilities} will always have a duration listed that tell you when they are and aren't in effect.

Note: @Wiki[Category:Passive abilities]{passive abilities} are in effect whether you like them or not. You can not simply choose to not use them.

Every @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} is @Wiki[Category:Powered abilities]{powered} through some means. For many @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}, the power source is simply "@Wiki[Category:Martially powered abilities]{martial}", which means they stem from the physical capabilities of the user. Other abilities could be "@Wiki[Category:Magically powered abilities]{magical}", "@Wiki[Category:Spiritually powered abilities]{spiritual}", or powered through other means. For an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} to work, all power sources must be accessible.

A character's presence tier is a numerical indicator of their capacity to passively maintain their will over magical artifacts, spirits, or other beings. As they level up, a character's presence tier will continue to increase. Magic items, mounts, and the like will typically have the required tier it takes to use them specified. A character can only maintain control over things with a total tier less than or equal to their presence tier. Using something that requires presence takes @Ability[Attune]{Attunement}. @Ability[Deattune]{Deattunement} is required to free up presence for another purpose. Whenever PRES is written, it refers to a character's total presence tier. UNP is a character's unused presence.

Note: This is just a generalization of Item Tiers from Roekron. Any item with an Item tier (even one where the tier isn't listed) is one that requires Presence.

When a creature @Condition[Dead]{dies} and is @Wiki[Category:Revival effects]{revived}, they release control over anything that is no longer on their person, freeing up the corresponding presence in the process. This includes @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{equipment} that is no longer equipped, mounts that no longer with them, and so on.

Sir Pignautilus is level 11 and therefore has a presence tier of 3. They can wield a magical tier 2 hammer than makes purple bubbles while riding a tier 1 mount. However, they wouldn't also be able to use a tier 1 ring of @Ability[Knockback]{Knockback} at the same time.

A character's proficiency bonus is a static bonus that applies to any [[/roll d20]] rolls that they are proficient in. Players can be proficient in @Wiki[Category:Tradecrafts]{tradecrafts}, @Core[Abilities]{abilities}, any many other things. However, the proficiency bonus is always the same and scales as a character levels up.

If you train in a @Wiki[Category:Classes]{class}, you are automatically proficient in its abilities so long as you are not wearing armor beyond that @Wiki[Category:Classes]{class'} @Core[Armor Class]{maximum AV}.

As a shorthand, your proficiency bonus may sometimes be written as "P".

An @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{item's} properties define additional @Wiki[Category:Effects]{effects} and rules that govern how it is used.
Each @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability} has some range over which it can be used. These depend on the @Wiki[Category:Delivery abilities]{delivery} and @Wiki[Category:Target abilities]{target}.

Reactive maneuvers can only be done in response to some event that triggers them. Every reactive maneuver will specify what its triggering conditions are. These could be @Ability[Tumble]{taking damage}, @Ability[Resolve Conflict]{hearing another creature speak}, @Ability[Opportunity Attack]{another creature moving away from you}, or anything else. Each creature has only one @Wiki[Category:Reaction abilities]{reaction} per turn. However, some @Wiki[Category:Reactive abilities]{reactive abilities} are @Wiki[Category:Free reaction abilities]{free reactions}. These have no limit on the number of times they can be used, so long as their triggering condition is met every time.

The order of reactive maneuver resolution is determined by a "last in, first out" stack. So if so if a creature casts @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball}, and another casts @Ability[Dispel Magic]{Dispel Magic}, and the creature that first cast @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball} casts @Ability[Dispel Magic]{Dispel Magic} on the first dispel, then the @Ability[Fire Ball]{Fire Ball} resolves. A given creature can only use a given @Wiki[Category:Reactive abilities]{reactive ability} once within a given stack.

Teriock Online has no concept of "encounters". Instead, everything is specified in @Core[Turns]{turns}, @Core[Rounds]{rounds}, time (minutes, seconds, days, etc.) or as short rests and long rests.

Short Rest

A short rest is a period of downtime, at least 1 hour long, during which a creature does nothing more strenuous than eating, drinking, reading, and tending to wounds. Some @Wiki[Category:Short rest abilities]{abilities} (such as @Ability[Recover]{Recover}) have "short rest" as their execution time. A creature may choose to do one of these during their short rest.

Note: Your @Core[GM]{GM} may decide on a different time period or conditions for a short rest.

Long Rest

A long rest is a period of extended downtime, at least 8 hours long, during which a creature sleeps or performs light activity: reading, talking, eating, or standing watch for no more than 2 hours. If the rest is interrupted by a period of strenuous activity—at least 1 hour of walking, fighting, casting spells, or similar adventuring activity—the creatures must begin the rest again to gain any benefit from it.

Note: Your @Core[GM]{GM} may decide on a different time period or conditions for a long rest.

Some @Wiki[Category:Long rest abilities]{abilities} (such as @Ability[Elder Sorcery Creation]{Elder Sorcery Creation}) have "long rest" as their execution time. A creature may choose to do one of these during their long rest.

At the end of a long rest, a creature regains all lost @Wiki[Core:HP]{HP}. The creature also regains all spent @Wiki[Core:HP]{hit dice}.

Someone receiving revitalizing may instantly spend a @Wiki[Core:MP]{mana die} to recover that many @Wiki[Core:MP]{MP}. If a creature that's @Condition[Unconscious]{unconscious} receives revitalizing, they are @Keyword[Awaken]{awakened}.

Each round of combat is considered to take 5 seconds.

Initiative

At the start of combat, every participant rolls for initiative ([[/roll 1d20]] + @Core[Movement]{MOV} + @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{P}). This determines the combatants' turn order, with the higher rollers acting first. If another creature joins the combat partway through, they roll initiative as well and can act at times in accordance with their roll.

Surprise Rounds

Sometimes abilities or other circumstances will allow some combatants to get the upper hand on their foes by surprising them at the start of combat. When this happens, everyone still rolls for initiative, but the creatures that benefit from the surprise round are the only ones that get to act. Everyone else has their turns skipped.

Self Sourced Abilities are the simplest ones. They have no special means of transmission, but simply come from the User. This is sometimes used as a catch-all for Abilities that don't fit with any other Source.
Self targeted @Core[Abilities]{abilities} affect @Core[Executer]{the creature that executes them}. They may not have a range specified.

@Wiki[Category:Shatter cost abilities]{Abilities with the shatter cost} are always delivered with some sort of @Wiki[Category:Item delivery abilities]{item}. As a cost of using the @Wiki[Category:Shatter cost abilities]{ability}, the @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{item} is @Property[Shattered]{shattered}. If the item cannot be @Property[Shattered]{shattered}, the @Wiki[Category:Shatter cost abilities]{ability} can still be used. The @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{item} must not already be @Property[Shattered]{shattered}.

A short rest is a period of downtime, at least 1 hour long, during which a creature does nothing more strenuous than eating, drinking, reading, and tending to wounds. Some @Wiki[Category:Short rest abilities]{abilities} (such as @Ability[Recover]{Recover}) have "short rest" as their execution time. A creature may choose to do one of these during their short rest.

Note: Your @Core[GM]{GM} may decide on a different time period or conditions for a short rest.

Abilities sourced by sight do not require the user to literally see the target with their eyeballs. While that's still necessary in most cases, some creatures may have some sort of "@Wiki[Category:Sensory effects]{blindsight}" that allows them to "see" other creatures even when there's no light in the environment. Nevertheless, these abilities always require that the user have some sort of direct "visibility" of the target akin to seeing them directly. Regardless of how exactly the user sees the target, sight abilities can be used over some range that may not actually be as far as the user can see. For instance, @Ability[Duel]{Duel} operates by sight, but has a range of 30 feet even though the user may see the target from much further away.

Slow maneuvers are those that take longer than a single turn to execute. Some may be on the scale of a @Wiki[Category:Short rest abilities]{short} or @Wiki[Category:Long rest abilities]{long rest}, in which case they cannot be used in combat. Other @Wiki[Category:Slow abilities]{slow abilities}, such as most @Wiki[Category:Ritual delivery abilities]{rituals}, have a more precise execution time (or casting time) specified in seconds, minutes, hours, or some other defined unit of time. These can be done during combat so long as a round doesn't pass without the creature executing them using @Ability[Sustain]{Sustain} at least once.

A creature's sneak (abbreviated as SNK) is a measure of how stealthy it is in both a physical and metaphysical sense. By default, a creature's SNK is determined by its @Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE}, but there are @Wiki[Category:SNK setting abilities]{various abilities that set it to different values}.

If an @Wiki[Category:Somatic component abilities]{ability} has a somatic component, the creature executing it must have at least one free hand to do so. If the creature has an @Damage[Hack]{arm hack} then it must have both hands free. If the creature has two @Damage[Hack]{arm hacks} then it cannot execute the @Wiki[Category:Somatic component abilities]{ability}.

Noted under the "delivery sources" section of an @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{ability}, is whether it is considered @Wiki[Category:Standard abilities]{standard}. These @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} are typically those given by @Wiki[Category:Classes]{classes} or those that are particularly common, well known, or easy to interact with. Some @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} interact specifically with other standard abilities. @Wiki[Category:Conjured spells]{Standard spells} are referred to as @Wiki[Category:Conjured spells]{conjured} and @Wiki[Category:Semblant skills]{standard skills} as @Wiki[Category:Semblant skills]{semblant}.
