130 + (40 × (STR + (@Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE} - 5)²)) @Condition[Encumbered]{Heavily Encumbered}
195 + (60 × (STR + (@Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE} - 5)²)) Cannot carry anything more

A creature may also push, drag, or lift a weight in pounds up to twice their carrying capacity. While pushing or dragging weight in excess of their carrying capacity, the creature's @Core[Movement Speed]{movement speed} drops to 5 feet.

Design Note: I have many spreadsheets of lame algebra to make sure the weight and carrying capacity scaling make physical sense (one has to scale on a power of 2 and the other on a power of 3), fit with our intuitions of strength on the human scale, and also allow creatures to be strong enough to carry their own bodies. It's actually a very limited set of values that that works for.
Design Note: Why use pounds instead of sizes? Because I hate the size abstraction, somehow still have no intuition for how many "sizes" of weight objects are, and it's also simplicity that isn't needed in the way it is for live action FanWar.

If an @Core[Attack Interaction]{attack} would have SB from multiple sources, it still only gets a +1 bonus to hit. However, SB stacks with other bonuses, such as those granted by @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency} or @Keyword[AV0]{AV0}.

Sometimes abilities or other circumstances will allow some combatants to get the upper hand on their foes by surprising them at the start of combat. When this happens, everyone still rolls for initiative, but the creatures that benefit from the surprise round are the only ones that get to act. Everyone else has their turns skipped.

A sustained @Wiki[Category:Sustained abilities]{ability} needs to be maintained throughout its duration. If a creature becomes @Keyword[Incapable]{incapable} of an @Wiki[Category:Sustained abilities]{ability} they're sustaining or otherwise loses the @Wiki[Category:Sustained abilities]{ability} then the effects of that @Wiki[Category:Sustained abilities]{ability} end.

An ability's target type determines what kinds of things can be affected by the Ability. Some of the most common ones are listed here.

Creature

Abilities with the Creature Target affect some sort of being. A "creature" doesn't necessarily have to be an animal, it may be an animated statue or a sentient plant. Check with your @Core[GM]{GM} if in doubt of whether something is a creature or not.

Limb

Rather than hitting an entire creature, some Abilities will say that they only hit arms, legs, or limbs. If these Abilities are @Core[Attack Interaction]{attacks}, then they slightly harder to land a hit with than ones that can hit a creature anywhere. They require hitting that creature's @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 2.

Vitals

Vitals Targeted Abilities need to hit a creature's head or other vital organs rather than landing anywhere. If these Abilities are @Core[Attack Interaction]{attacks}, then they require hitting a creature's @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 3.

Item

@Wiki[Category:Item target abilities]{Attacks that target items} need different @Core[Attack Interaction]{hit rolls} depending on the @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{type of item}.

  • Wielded items (such as @Wiki[Category:Weapons]{weapons} or @Wiki[Category:Shields]{shields}): @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 3 - @Core[Block Interaction]{BV}
  • Large worn items (such as @Wiki[Category:Armor]{armor} or cloaks): @Core[Armor Class]{AC}
  • @Wiki[Category:Small equipment]{Small} @Wiki[Category:Searchable equipment]{searchable items} (such as rings or amulets): @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 6

If an @Wiki[Category:Item target abilities]{ability that targets an item} is successfully @Core[Block Interaction]{blocked}, it automatically hits the item that @Core[Block Interaction]{blocked} it.

Area

Abilities that Target an Area do not have a precisely defined size. Rather than affect a small, cohesive space such as a campsite, a room in a dungeon, or a small shack.These abilities may not have a Range specified.

Self

Self targeted @Core[Abilities]{abilities} affect @Core[Executer]{the creature that executes them}. They may not have a range specified.

Ability

Instead of targeting some person, place, or other physical thing, some @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities} target other @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}. These include cases that target @Wiki[Category:Attack target abilities]{attack target abilities}, @Wiki[Category:Conjured spells]{conjured} @Wiki[Category:Spell target abilities]{spells}, or other types of @Wiki[Category:Abilities]{abilities}.

Other

Some Ability Targets don't fit nearly into one of the aforementioned categories. In these cases, the Ability's Target will just say "Other".

Temporary Hit Points (temp HP) are not actual @Wiki[Core:HP]{HP}; they are a buffer against damage. When you have temp HP and take damage, your temp HP are reduced first, and any remaining damage carries over to your normal @Wiki[Core:HP]{HP}. If the @Wiki[Category:Damage types]{type of damage} is not one that would reduce @Wiki[Core:HP]{HP} (such as @Damage[Hack]{hack damage}), then your temp HP has no effect on the damage and is not reduced. You cannot spent temp HP as an @Wiki[Category:HP cost abilities]{HP cost}.

As you rank up, you get the option to take additional tradecrafts, or gain a fluency in a tradecraft you already have. A tradecraft fluency is a more tailored form of the tradecraft it corresponds to. For instance, you could be a @Tradecraft[Historian]{historian} with a fluency in ancient Shaloban history, a @Tradecraft[Tailor]{tailor} with a fluency in wizard robes, or an @Tradecraft[Enforcer]{enforcer} with a fluency in intimidating homeless people. When you make a tradecraft check where your fluency is relevant, you add your @Core[Fluency Bonus]{fluency bonus} (F) instead of your @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} (P) to the roll. The @Core[GM]{GM} may also tailor the results of your check with regards to your fluency.

Game Master
You find what looks like an old pirate map.
Player
Can I try and make out the symbols on it? I'm a @Tradecraft[Cartographer]{cartographer} with a fluency in nautical directions.
Game Master
Sure thing. Roll for it.
Player
Rolls [[/roll 1d20+6]] because they're fluent in this and @Core[Leveling Up]{level 29}.
I rolled 19.
Game Master
You recognize a lot of the markings as referring to whirlpools and sea dragons. It's your choice whether you want to avoid or go into those areas.

Tradecrafts are used for tradecraft checks. These arise either when some rules text specifies (such as in @Ability[First Aid]{First Aid}), or when the @Core[GM]{GM} tells you to attempt one. When this happens, you roll [[/roll 1d20]] and, if proficient in the associated tradecraft, you add your @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency bonus} (P). You do not need to be proficient in a tradecraft to attempt a tradecraft check.

Note: Tradecrafts have no levels associated with them. This differs from live action FanWar. You either have a given tradecraft @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficiency} or you don't.
Game Master
The blacksmith says "What? I'm not a vampire! I've never even seen a vampire! I walk around in the sun all the time. It's my favorite thing to do, other than bloodsipping. Er, I mean blacksmithing! I'm a blacksmith. Blacksmithing is what I do."
Player
Do I think that he's lying?
Game Master
Attempt a @Tradecraft[Peacekeeper]{peacekeeper} check.
Player
Rolls [[/roll 1d20]] with no bonus because they're not proficient in this.
I rolled a 6.
Game Master
You can see blood dripping from the corner of his mouth, bite marks on the side of his neck, and a corpse that looks just like Flumbo sticking out of a barrel. Yeah he's totally lying.
Game Master
You see some markings on the dungeon wall. They're poorly carved and not easy to make out.
Player
Can I do a @Tradecraft[Scribe]{scribe} check to try to see what they say?
Game Master
Sure. Go ahead.
Player
Rolls [[/roll 1d20+2]] because they're @Core[Proficiency Bonus]{proficient} in @Tradecraft[Scribe]{scribe} and @Core[Leveling Up]{level 18}.
I got a 21.
Game Master
The carvings are incomplete and have a lot of mistakes in them. You don't think whoever wrote them was very good at Common, but you can piece together the details. It looks like it says "Flumbo was here."
Player
I note that down in my Carnivore's Almanac.
Game Master
Noted.

List of Tradecrafts

What follows are the main tradecrafts that are available in Teriock Online. The @Core[GM]{GM} will typically pick checks that correspond to one of these.

Artisan Tradecrafts

Tradecraft Description
@Tradecraft[Artist]{Artist} Artist checks can be used to create and evaluate works of art.
@Tradecraft[Blacksmith]{Blacksmith} Blacksmith checks can be used to forge @Wiki[Category:Armor]{armor}, @Wiki[Category:Weapons]{weapons}, and other metal goods. It can also be used to understand the make and quality of metal @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{items}.
@Tradecraft[Builder]{Builder} Builder checks can be used to build and repair wooden or stone objects and structures. It can also be used to understand the make and quality of such objects and structures.
@Tradecraft[Chef]{Chef} Chef checks can be used to cook, prepare, serve, and evaluate food.
@Tradecraft[Locksmith]{Locksmith} Locksmith checks can be used to assemble, pick, and evaluate locks.
@Tradecraft[Mariner]{Mariner} Mariner checks can be used to sail and understand @Wiki[Category:Ship target abilities]{ships} and the sea. It can also be used to understand the workings of ships and how to repair them.
@Tradecraft[Tailor]{Tailor} Tailor checks can be used to sew and repair clothing and other cloth @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{items}. It can also be used to understand the make and quality of cloth @Wiki[Category:Equipment]{items}.

Mediator Tradecrafts

Tradecraft Description
@Tradecraft[Courtier]{Courtier} Courtier checks can be used to befriend, manipulate, and deceive, and adjust the attitudes of other cratures.
@Tradecraft[Enforcer]{Enforcer} Enforcer checks can be used to intimidate others and appear authoritative.
@Tradecraft[Gambler]{Gambler} Gambler checks can be used to play games of skill or luck and assess the odds of things.
@Tradecraft[Innkeeper]{Innkeeper} Innkeeper checks can be used to find information about other people and hear or spread rumors.
@Tradecraft[Peacekeeper]{Peacekeeper} Peacekeeper checks can be used to know if other creatures are attempting to lie or deceive you.
@Tradecraft[Performer]{Performer} Performer checks can be used to impress, entertain, and distract other creatures. It can also be used to recognize or evaluate the quality of performances.
@Tradecraft[Trader]{Trader} Trader checks can be used to make deals with other creatures and find opportunities to trade that wouldn't otherwise be available.

Scholarly Tradecrafts

Tradecraft Description
@Tradecraft[Cartographer]{Cartographer} Cartographer checks can be used to navigate and read or make maps.
@Tradecraft[Diplomat]{Diplomat} Diplomat checks can be used to understand the law and navigate the political landscape.
@Tradecraft[Historian]{Historian} Historian checks can be used to research and understand past events as well as the people, places, and items associated with them.
@Tradecraft[Messenger]{Messenger} Messenger checks can be used to recall words, phrases, and other information you have encountered previously.
@Tradecraft[Priest]{Priest} Priest checks can be used to tend shrines or temples and understand theology.
@Tradecraft[Scribe]{Scribe} Scribe checks can be used to speak, read, and write in Common or other languages.
@Tradecraft[Teacher]{Teacher} Teacher checks can be used to train others and share your knowledge.

Survivalist Tradecrafts

Tradecraft Description
@Tradecraft[Farmer]{Farmer} Farmer checks can be used to grow and tend crops or gardens to produce food. It can also be used to recognize edible plants.
@Tradecraft[Herbalist]{Herbalist} Herbalist checks can be used to gather herbs and prepare herbal remedies. It can also be used to apply basic medicine to other creatures.
@Tradecraft[Hunter]{Hunter} Hunter checks can be used to trap or hunt animals for food and hides. It can also be used to know what parts of animals are useful for different purposes.
@Tradecraft[Investigator]{Investigator} Investigator checks can be used to search areas for hidden objects. It can also be used to hide objects.
@Tradecraft[Miner]{Miner} Miner checks can be used to find your way in or out of caves and dungeons. It can also be used to understand the properties of minerals and ores.
@Tradecraft[Tamer]{Tamer} Tamer checks can be used to tame, calm, or rile up wild and domesticated animals. It can also be used to intuit an animal's intentions.
@Tradecraft[Tracker]{Tracker} Tracker checks can be used to find your way in the wild and follow or evade others.

On a creature's turn, they may make up to three actions. @Ability[Move]{Moving}, @Wiki[Category:Attack abilities]{attacking}, and so on typically use some number of these actions. Creatures also have one reaction that can, in principle, be use at any time within a round. They regain their reaction at the start of their turn. Creatures cannot "save up" their actions or reactions between rounds or turns. Actions and reactions reset regardless of whether or not they're used.

In addition, some effects may begin, apply, or cease at the start or end of a creature's turn. These are specified within the relevant rules text.
If an @Wiki[Category:Verbal component abilities]{ability} has a verbal component, the creature executing it must be able to speak to do so. The must not be @Condition[Deaf]{deaf}.

Vitals Targeted Abilities need to hit a creature's head or other vital organs rather than landing anywhere. If these Abilities are @Core[Attack Interaction]{attacks}, then they require hitting a creature's @Core[Armor Class]{AC} + 3.

A creature's weight is determined by its @Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE}. Typically, it is equal to (3 + @Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE})³ lb. However, there is some variation from creature to creature. The actual weight could be anything from (3 + (@Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE} - 0.5))³ lb. to (3 + (@Wiki[Core:Size]{SIZE} + 0.5))³ lb. Creatures with a size of 0.5 typical have a weight of 15 lb.
